characters: MIKE, ALICE, THE BRADY KIDS, ROCKY AND JUNIOR
CAMERA ZEROES IN ON OUTSIDE PRISON WALL AND DIRT AREA

dialogues.speaker: "BRADY" THEME OVER MAIN TITLE CREDITS
dialogues.text: The familiar checkerboard "Brady" blue, just as we oneys saw at the beginning of the television show. CAROL, MARCIA, JAN, CINDY, all pop onto the screen; then MIKE, GREG, PETER, BOBBY, pop onto the screen, and we are amazed at the similarity of the new Bradys to the origina Bradys. Mike and Greg sport the 1970’s big curly hair, and Peter and Bobby’s hair is long, too. Carol has her fli which all America remembers. Marcia and Jan have their beautiful long hair as before, and Cindy "the youngest one in curls". Jan wears glasses as she did in the later episodes. As the theme continues they all look around in every direction. Then ALICE, in her unremovable blue uniform, takes her place in the center box just as the theme ends. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very familiar Brady house in all its suburban glory. INT. BOYS’ BEDROOM - DAY - CLOSE ANGLE - BATHROOM DOOR Greg’s fist pounds on the door, and WE PULL BACK AND WIDE to see the frustrated Greg, Peter, and Bobby -- as well as the familiar bunk bedded boys’ bedroom. The boys are in robes and pajamas. _

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Marcia, will you come out of there? We have to get ready to rehearse!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yeah! Stop brushing your hair!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Marcia, I’ve got to go! INT. KIDS’ BATHROOM MARCIA . . Sixty-three, sixty-four, sixty- five... INT. GIRLS’ BEDROOM on this side of the door, Jan and Cindy -- in pajamas -- are equally antsy and huddled at the door.

dialogues.speaker: JAN .,
dialogues.text: We want to get in there, Marcia. We've got hair, too, you know. Cindy pulls her own trademark pigtails in opposite directions.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (fluffing her curls) I’ve got hair on both sides. INT. KIDS’ BATHROOM

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: Seventy-two, seventy-three, seventy-four... INT. BOYS’ BEDROOM Bobby is dancing from one foot to another foot. Greg sees Bobby’s dam is about to burst. Bobby starts toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: GREG -
dialogues.text: Bobby, not out the window! cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NOTE: A word about the backyard: it’s exactly the same as the Brady yard we remember. Except it’s real grass instead of articial turf; a real backyard.) In addition to the usual Brady objects in the backyard, the yard is cluttered with remnants of various episodes; a teeter-totter, Greg's surfboard, a club house, and, of course, Tiger’s doghouse. TIGER, who had been lost after the first-season’s episodes, has found his way back home for this film. One major addition has been made to the backyard. It’s a practice platform for the Brady kids to rehearse their song and dance numbers. _ It’s about a foot high and ten by six, with different size circular platforms for each of the kids to stand on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As all six Brady kids stream out‘of the family room now dressed in regular 1973 clothes; bellbottom pants, mini-skirts, etc. They are jabbering excitedly as they head for the rehearsal platform.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Pete, punch the button, Peter crosses to a tape recorder (1973 version) and start the music accompaniment. Then he quickly hops up on the platform with the rest of the kids as the music starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPENING CREDITS roll as the Brady kids rehearse the numbe They each have half a jump rope to simulate a mike and cord. Jan sings the lead.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: As the music ends, Greg shuts off the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: There! I did the lead, and I Was really good.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we’re not doing that song in the contest. We’re doing "Good Time Music".

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (snidely) Oh, where you and Marcia have the lead.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: That’s right, Jan.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: That’s how it always is. Marcia sings the lead vocal. Marcia gets the lead in the school play. Marcia gets a new boyfriend. Marcia, Marcia, Marcia!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Jan, cheer up. They’re not letting me sing lead vocal either.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: That’s because we want to win. Your voice cracks like a broken mirror.’

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Marcia sings an impression of Peter’s voice cracking in "Time to Change".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARCIA “ (singing and cracking) When it’s time to change, then it’s time to change...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Look who thinks she’s a prima dona.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: What’s a prima dona?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: {not knowing either) Everybody knows what a prima dona is. Don’t you know anything, Cindy? CINDY n Sure. I know that you -don’t know what a prima dona is either. Cindy sticks her tongue out at him. Meanwhile: _

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Look, this is the amateur finals at the Hollywood Bowl. And we have to win first prize. We’ve got to put our best face forward.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with my face?

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA /
dialogues.text: Would you like that in alphabetical order? Jan flies at Marcia and grabs her hair and starts to pull In return, Marcia grabs Jan’s hair, and starts to pull. There’s a lot of yelling as Greg and Peter try to pull th girls apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and Alice are at the stove in the good old orange and olive colored kitchen, circa 1973. They can see the backyard through the windows in the den. They can also hear the racket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALICE a Re Doesn’t sound much like music to me, . Mrs. Brady.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I'd better go out there, and put some harmony into the act. As Alice stirs something on the stove, Carol strides “!* purposefully to the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Carol enters, and moves quickly toward Jan and Marcia, who are still tugging at each other’s hair. Carol gets between them.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Girls, cut this out! As the girls separate:

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA ,
dialogues.text: Jan started it. a

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: No, I didn’t. Marcia started it. The . day I was born. BS

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We're Bradys. Bradys don’t fight with each other. a Those are magic words.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA/JAN
dialogues.text: (contritely) Sorry, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Now why don’t you change into your -regular clothes, so you’1ll be ready for dinner when Dad gets home? Now that order has been restored, Carol returns to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking a look around. It’s exactly as remembered, from a the open-stepped stairway to the ceramic horse. Carol is in the alcove at the dining room table and is fluffing up the floral centerpiece -- one of her primary occupations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike enters with his briefcase and calls out the expected...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hi, Honey, I’m home.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Perking up at the news, she meets him in the center of th room. She kisses him. He savors it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (continuing) With greetings like that, I should stop Sy by two or three times a: day.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Just what I told the milkman. They share a laugh. Mike puts down his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well, which one of the kids needs a lecture?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: How’d you guess?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No guess. Between us, we’ve got six kids. Somebody always needs a lecture. CAROL ° Jan. po “MIKE Marcia, Marcia, Marcia?

dialogues.speaker: _ CAROL
dialogues.text: (confirming) Marcia, Marcia, Marcia. FLIP TO o  INT. MIKE’S DEN - NIGHT The small room just off the living room. It’s down three steps to the loveseat and drafting table. It’s the Brady equivalent of the wood shed. Jan is hearing it from Mike and Carol.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Marcia, Marcia, Marcia. That’s all I hear. It’s enough to make me puke.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Bradys don’t talk like that.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Sorry, Dad, but it’s just not fair. She’s got pretty hair, and a pretty face. I’ve got glasses and braces.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You’ve also got a family that loves you.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Big wow.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Jan, right now Marcia seems to have it all. :

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That’s right, sweetheart. Your turn will come.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: That’s what you’ve been telling me since I was two.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You just have to be patient. There’s an old Chinese proverb, "Patience is the greatest virtue".

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, I’m sick of being virtuous, too. With that, Jan storms out of the roon.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I know just how she feels. When I was a little girl, I felt the same way about my sister.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You don’t have a sister.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL '
dialogues.text: Not anymore. I killed her. i Mike hits her with a sofa pillow. cuT TO |

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA ZEROES IN ON OUTSIDE PRISON WALL AND DIRT AREA
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES IN FURTHER TO SHOW there is movement in the dirt. Then more movement. Then the dirt seems to be falling back into the prison. Then we see a big kitchen spoon. Then the hand holding the spoon. The hand has a distinctive tattoo with the numbers: 1,2,3, hand etched. WIDER SHOT - CAMERA MOVES WIDER © as the crewcutted ROCKY pulls himself out of the hole int freedom outside the prison wall. He is dressed in traditional prison clothes. Then CLARENCE, a huge Black convict, emerges after Rocky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCREECHING UP in a 1964 Valiant is Rocky’s nineteen year old son, JUNIOR. Barely slowing down, Junior opens up the passenger side door. :

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Dad. Then Junior sees Clarence. JUNIOR a (continuing) . Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Never mind. Let’s move it. Rocky and Clarence jump in. As the car speeds away, SIREN GO OFF in the prison, and searchlights scan the area. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR .
dialogues.text: You never said there’d be two of you.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Clarence was my cellmate. And he deserved a break today. Clarence doesn’t say anything. He has a hulking presence and rarely speaks.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) You bring everything? Junior hands Rocky a package. He opens it and takes out two guns and a six pack of beer.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: There it is, Dad. One six pack and two guns. I guess the other gun is for Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Good guess, kid. Rocky realizes which car they're in.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: _ (continuing) This is the car I bought you, ain’t it

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Very smart. Busting me out in your own car. They’1ll tag us for sure. :

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: I don’t have much experience driving a getaway car. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Just drive, smart ass. Junior turns from his father and speeds along faster. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black and white is parked. TWO POLICEMEN are leaning back, relaxing, their hats pushed back.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Finally, a few minutes » ‘to relax. CoP #2 Yeah. It’s been a rough night.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE DISPATCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All units, be on the lookout for an escaped prisoner, Rocky Portugal. He is believed to be armed and dangerous and in his son’s blue Valiant, license plate MRT 874 and traveling west from Chino. Escaping with Portugal is Clarence Dawkins, former bodyguard to crime kingpin, Willy the Mongoose.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Can‘’t guys bust out in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Valiant screams down the street and passes the cop ca

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The cops can’t believe that it’s the escape vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: MRT 874! Thar she blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: HARD DRIVING 1970’S SONG ("BORN TO BE WILD"

dialogues.speaker: STEPPENWOLF
dialogues.text: Junior is a good driver and manages to elude the cops. He cuts off a car, and makes a hard left onto the Santa Monica Freeway heading west to the Pacific Coast Highway. Then under the overpass and onto the coast route itself. The cops come alongside, but Junior uses a moving van as interference to lose them as the pursuers go up the coast and Junior speeds up the ramp. cuUT TO

dialogues.speaker: . JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Well, we lost them.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Like hell! We better blow off this bus. Rocky sees a cliff to the side.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Pull over. Junior does so. Then the boy sees the cliff and understands his father’s plan.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Come on, Dad. The car’s got sentimental value.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Just get out. If you can’t say goodbye to your wheels, leave the drivin’ to me. Clarence gets out. Then Junior gets out. Rocky hands his son the beer and guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocky steps on the gas, and careens toward the cliff. Jus before the car goes over, Rocky bails out and tumbles to the ground. The car sails through the air then smashes t9 the ground where it breaks apart and bursts into flames.

dialogues.speaker: AANGLE
dialogues.text: Rocky gets up and dusts himself off as Junior walks up to him. Junior looks distraught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles as he enjoys watching the car explode. .

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Rocky takes back the guns and beer.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Don’t be getting teary, Junior. As long as we got guns, we can always get another car.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: we 12

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: I had some books and drawings in the back seat. Rocky takes a folded map from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: The only drawing you ever made worth spit was this map of the prison. you got every one of them pipes and wires in the right place, or me and Clarence never coulda dug our way out. Clarence joins them.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Right, Clarence? Clarence nods. Rocky pockets the drawing and starts off down the street. Junior and Clarence follow. cUuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocky, Junior and Clarence move down the block. Rocky seems to be looking for something.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: They all look the same to me.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: We need the right house. We need money, and we need a car. ANGLE - HOUSES - PAN SHOT - ROCKY’S POV Rocky and Junior look at the houses and the camera linger at the Brady house. It seems to have a faint glow around it, and the muted STRAINS OF THE "BRADY" THEME make it ev more obvious what their choice will be.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: That’s the house, Junior.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Sure, I’m sure. Whoever lives here has gotta have cars, and plenty of dough. Junior and Clarence follow as Rocky goes down the drivewa and into the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pause at the garage and look inside.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Six bicycles? Six kids? They gotta be crazy. Rocky and Junior move to the far side of the backyard and case the joint. Clarence hangs back, as a lookout, listening for any unusual sounds.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) This place is perfect....We’1ll hang out til morning. After the kids go to school, we’1l move in, take some money, some clothes, grab a car and get out.

dialogues.speaker: TIGER
dialogues.text: The Bradys’ sheepdog, Tiger, comes out of his doghouse, sees the two intruders and starts barking. Rocky raises a gun, and aims it at Tiger. Junior pulls his arm down.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Dad, it’s just a dog. Tiger ignores the warning and keeps barking. cuT TO INT. MIKE AND CAROL’S BEDROOM Mike and Carol hear Tiger and wake up. They turn on the lamps on the nightstands. Both of their bathrobes are carefully laid out on the foot of his bed.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Mike, is that Tiger?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It must be. That’s the only dog we’ve got.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Want to go see what’s bothering him?
Obeying her suggestion, he gets out of bed, puts on one sleeve of his robe, then thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Why don’t we give it a minute? Chances are Tiger just saw a squirrel or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiger is still holding Rocky, Junior and Clarence at bay.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: People would hear a shot, Dad. Some food would keep him quiet.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Hey, we got better thar food. With that, Rocky takes a beer can, pops the top, and pour some in Tiger’s water dish. Tiger immediately shuts up, laps up the lager and hiccups.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. MIKE AND CAROL’S BEDROOM - ANGLE - MIKE He reacts to the fact that Tiger stopped barking.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: See? I told you it was nothing. (then, romantically) . But as long as Tiger woke us up -- Mike starts to take off his robe, then hops into bed. He eases over toward Carol’s side, then reacts as he sees Carol is fast asleep. He shrugs, and prepares for a less active night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: (“EVERYTHING IS BEAUTIFUL" ~ RAY STEVENS OR

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: AS CAMERA SURVEYS the room. As ‘seen in the first scene, each wall area is individualized for the child sleeping in the bed underneath it. Cindy has the pretty picture of a cat. Marcia has a picture of Darryl, and Jan has an evil punk rock poster. SLOW PAN of the sleeping girls. Cindy is sleeping with her favorite doll, Kitty Karry-All Marcia has an angelic smile. When the camera reaches Jan, her eyes are open. She has a diabolical look and quietly sneaks out of bed. She crosses to the desk and removes a pair of wicked looking scissors. She skulks back to the sleeping Marcia. Jan takes the scissors and -- miraculously without waking Marcia -- cuts away at her older sister’s long blonde hair.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Cindy awakens, and sees Jan hovering "Norman Bates-like" over Marcia.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (in a horrified whisper) Jan, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jan continues to cut Marcia’s locks...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Something I should have done a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t do that to Marcia. She’s so pretty.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, I’m a little sick of everybody telling me how pretty Marcia is.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Stop it. Stop it right now.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You know something? You really bug me, too. Jan crosses quickly to Cindy and -- with a well-timed sni -- clips off one of Cindy’s pigtails. Twirling it like a trophy she hops back to her bed and settles down victoriously.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Jan, no! Jan, no! Cindy screams. This wakes up the shorn Marcia who feels her head and crosses to the mirror. She screams in anguish. Now Marcia and Cindy are both screaming and Jan is smiling. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: Jan! Jan!

dialogues.speaker: JAN IN BED
dialogues.text: With a contented smile, Jan is blissfully asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (continuing) Jan! Jan, wake up, for school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE PULL BACK and discover it was.all a dream. Both Marcia and Cindy have all their hair. dan looks at both of them.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Darn it.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I was just dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: Was it a nightmare?

dialogues.speaker: . JAN
dialogues.text: No. Best dream I ever had. _As Jan gets out of bed and heads for the bathroom...

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Greg, Peter, Bobby...You better not be in there. I’ve got to go. She enters. cut To  17

dialogues.speaker: THE CHART
dialogues.text: Taking up a good portion of the wall is the activity char Each of the kids has a column, and written in is the day’ activities. On Sunday, church is for each, but the other days have cheerleading practice, Little League, football practice, glee club, drama class, Sunflower Girls, Fronti Scouts, etc., etc. PULL BACK TO find Alice making breakfast. She has a plate of hotcakes and puts them on the table. She whistles her Alice whistle.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hotcakes, everybody! Alice then steps to the entranceway to the kitchen, and awaits the thundering herd. Peter is first.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) You/re always first, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I like to get ‘em when they’re hot. He sits down and starts to eat immediately.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENTRANCEWAY
dialogues.text: Now, everyone else enters the kitchen, and takes their places at the table.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I’ve got hotcakes for everyone -- that is if Peter decides to leave you any.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No hotcakes for me, Alice. I’m watching my figure.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Jan, don’t you think you should have a figure before you start watching it?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Thanks, Alice. That’s just what I needed.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How’s rehearsal going, gang?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Real groovy, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Yeah. And if we win the big amateur night contest, we’ll be able to --

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE TABLE
dialogues.text: As Greg kicks Cindy’s foot.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You’1l be able to what?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (trying to cover) We’ll be able to win. Like you always say, Dad. “There’s more to winning than coming in first."

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well put, Greg.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Are you going to rehearse this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Not today. I’ve got football practice.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: I’ve got cheerleading practice.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I’ve got detention.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m bringing in my volcano for the science fair. I’m hoping for a major eruption.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Then you better rehearse your number tomorrow before the show.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: My Sunflower Girl troop is meeting here.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I’ve got my Little League Game.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You know, kids, Stephen MacKenna once said, “All good is gained by those whose thoughts and life are kept pointed to “one main thing, not scattered abroad upon a thousand"...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL AND BOBBY
dialogues.text: As they react to this philosophy.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Who’s Stephen MacKenna?-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Someone very famous, Bobby. You know your father only quotes very famous people.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: While you‘re doing all these things, the other acts will be rehearsing.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Thank goodness we’re very talented. GREG . We'll rehearse tonight, Dad. After dinner.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He is watching the TV on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, look at this. A couple of guys escaped from prison by digging under the wall.  20

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Right on.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: "Right on?" When they get caught, they’11l lose any chance of parole.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: Rocky Portugal and Clarence Dawkins are believed to be in the Santa Monica area. Portugal is a male Caucasion, and has a distinctive tattoo with the numbers 1-2-3 on his right hand. Dawkins is a large Black man, with a scar on his left cheek. On the screen is a picture of Rocky, and then one of Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER
dialogues.text: In other news, some survivors of the air crash in the Andes: Mountains admit to eating other victims who had frozen. They say it was only as a last resort but that their friends tasted kind of like --

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Carol quickly turns off the TV so the children won’t hear the rest of the report.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: How gross.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I think it’s neat. Marcia, wouldn’t you rather eat Cindy than die?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Mom, tell Jan to stop.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Jan, it’s not nice to talk about eating your sister.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Your mother’s right. Not at breakfast anyway. Mike looks at his watch and realizes he’s late.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Got to run. The big Riverside project. CAROL . We‘ve all got to go. Let’s head them up and move them out.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: All right. All luncheaters line up. The kids get ina line, and Alice grabs a lunch at a time and like a pitching machine delivers it to the proper child. Bobby and Cindy are the only ones with lunch boxes

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I‘ll be home this afternoon, Alice. I’ve got my anti-smoking committee or my anti-grafitti committee. I’m not sure exactly, but I know it’s my anti- -something committee. The family all adlib good-byes to ) Alice and leaves. The exit through the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And cross through before exiting into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brady family crosses to the two cars. Mike takes Greg and Marcia. Carol takes Peter, Jan, Bobby and Cindy. They buckle their seat belts and drive out, and WE PAN to the edge of the garage where Rocky and Junior step out.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: There really are six kids. What were they thinking?

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Okay. Everybody's gone. Let’s get in, and get out.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: That’s my boy. But first... Rocky adds a little more beer to Tiger’s water dish. Tiger immediately starts to lap it up. Then Rocky and Junior move to the family room door and enter.  22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice finishes clearing the table and goes into her room. Just as she exits, Rocky and Junior enter the kitchen. A near miss. They stop to munch on a few leftover hotcakes. They think they’re alone in the house now. Rocky looks around critically. i

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: An orange kitchen? How can anybody eat in here? cuT To INT. ALICE’S BEDROOM A spartan maid’s room with a smiling picture of Sam tucke into the mirror. Also, a picture of Alice with the Brady family on the dresser. Alice enters and goes to her phone on the nightstand. She starts to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. SAM’S BUTCHER SHOP SAM, the butcher and Alice’s longtime boyfriend, is helpi a customer, MRS. STONE, in his small establishment.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Are these lamb chops fresh, Mrs. Stone? Last night while I was sleeping, I counted them jumping over the fence. Sam laughs at his own joke.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STONE
dialogues.text: Sam, you’re lucky. The meat is always fresher than your jokes.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (laughing) That will be six-fifty. Sam takes the money as the phone rings. He answers it as the customer exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. ALICE’S BEDROOM

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hiya, Alice. What can I do for my girl this morning?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I just called to remind you about tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: . SAM
dialogues.text: No need to remind me. 1/11 be there with my bowling ball and my 136 average.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Sam, nobody bowls at the Hollywood Bowl. The kids are competing in the finals of the amateur contest.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I know, but Alice, what about my team? You don’t want me to let down the Bowling Butchers.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Of course not, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh, Alice. That’s not.fair. I went to see Marcia in Romeo-and Juliet; I went to see the Bradys in the school talent show. Heck, I even acted in Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. I’ve got my own life, too, Alice. The whole world doesn’t revolve around the Bradys.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Fine, Sam. And you know what you can do with your bowling ball. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocky and Junior are eating the last of the leftover breakfast food. CAMERA FOLLOWS them as they exit the kitchen and cross into the living roon.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Hey, look at this place! Some of this stuff could be worth a fortune. Clarence picks up the ceramic horse. Rocky taps it.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing, disgusted) Plaster of paris. Junk.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Junior picks up "the vase".

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Maybe this is worth something. Junior examines it.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: (continuing) No. It’s broken, and glued back together.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: The only thing I hate worse than rich guys is cheap rich guys. He smashes the vase for spite. Rocky leads the others toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continues) While we're waiting for Mom to come back with the car, let’s scope out the rest of the place. ae As soon as they disappear around the upstairs hallway, Alice enters with a dust rag. She finds the pieces of the vase, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Peter, you’re in trouble again. She puts the pieces back together and moves up the stairway, dusting the banister on her way up. INT. MIKE AND CAROL’S BEDROOM Rocky is opening all the drawers. He looks through a jewelry box, finds several gold chains. He hands them to Clarence, who bites on them, and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: The guy is too cheap to buy his wife real gold. He’s keeping it all in cash someplace.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Why don’t we just grab a car and go? Why do we need so much money?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Clarence has some friends who can make us some fake I.D.’s and passports, so we can get out of the country.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ved

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: They want cash.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Some world. Nobody trusts anybody. : Rocky pulls the cover off the bed and checks under the mattress. They find nothing very valuable. He looks in Mike’s closet, pulls out some drab sports jackets.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: One thing for sure, the clown’s not spending it on clothes. He throws the clothes down.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s hiding it in some other room.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Come on. All three exit Mike and Carol’s bedroom and enter the upstairs hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk toward the girls’ bedroom. As soon as they pass the walk-in linen closet, Alice exits into the hallway wi an armload of towels and sheets. She doesn’t see then; nor they her. They enter the girls’ bedroom. Alice enters Mike and Carol’s bedroom. INT. MIKE AND CAROL’S BEDROOM Alice puts her load down on the bureau and looks at the mess that Rocky has made.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Brady never left their room like this before. Maybe they really got into it. Maybe Mr. Brady tore off her clothes, and threw her on the floor and -- (reacts) Mr. and Mrs. Brady??? Nahhh!!... She shakes her head and goes to work straightening up.  ees 27 INT. GIRLS’ BEDROOM | Alice freezes as she hears the toy from the other room.

dialogues.speaker: SEE AND SPEAK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "A duck goes quack, quack." Alice looks around for a weapon in the girl’s bedroom. All she can find is an umbrella with a 60’s flower design Scared, but determined, she starts through the bathroom to the boys’ bedroom. She knocks} into the desk as she goes. INT. BOYS’ BEDROOM Rocky freezes as he hears the noise from the boys’ bedroo

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (whispering) We've got company. (then loudly) We've got guns!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. BATHROOM oy Alice is terrified. She opens the umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, I’ve got an umbrella. With that, she realizes the folly|of her position and run out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice races for the stairway. Rocky, Junior and Clarence enter the hallway and follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: _In a desperate effort to escape, Alice slides down the banister. As she does, the umbrella pops open. Junior and Clarence follow as each slides down the banister and cut her off as Rocky points his gun at her as he walks do the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Hold it right there, Mary Poppins. Alice stops in her tracks as. she gets to the living room Rocky, Junior and Clarence join her.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (nervously) You’re not going to do anything to me, are you? Rocky looks at her -- not exactly his type of woman.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Are you serious? I was only in prison three years. |

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: We want some money.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: If you know what’s good for you, you better take us to the money.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don’t know where it is. I’m only the housekeeper. Mr. and Mrs. Brady? I hardly know them. Heck, I can’t even keep the kids straight.;, Greg, Marcia, Happy, Bashful, Dopey, Prancer, Donner, Blitzen?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Have they got a safe?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: How should I know? Rocky makes a more threatening gesture with his gun. Alic gives in.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Right this way. Alice leads them back up the stairs and through the hallway. INT. MIKE AND CAROLS’ BEDROOM They enter. Alice crosses to the dresser. Over the dresser is a large portrait of the Bradys, the one along the stairs. Alice swings the portrait away from the wall to reveal a wall safe. Junior looks at Mike’s architectur degree on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: nal 29

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Now that’s more like it. What’s the combination?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Rocky menaces her with the gun again.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: + (continuing) Honest, I don’t know. I’m just the housekeeper. Why else would I wear this dumb blue uniform? Think about it. Would you tell your housekeeper the combination to your safe? I could be a crook or something. (realizing) Not that I have anything against crooks. Junior indicates the framed degree.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: They got to have money: . The guy’s an architect.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Too bad the safe won’t open. I guess you’ll be running along, huh?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Bad guess. We're going to wait for Mr. and Mrs.....

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Brady.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Right. Brady.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: They’re not expected home for a long long time.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Then it will be a long long wait. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA .
dialogues.text: Marcia, the head cheerleader (What else?) is leading the CHEERLEADING SQUAD in a B - E ~ A - R - S cheer with a lo of kicking and pompoming. All are real cute. MISS STANDFAST, the cheerleading advisor comes over to the girls.

dialogues.speaker: MISS STANDFAST
dialogues.text: Now, girls, that was very good. But if you all pay attention to Marcia, you’1l1 see how to do it exactly right. Marcia? Marcia does it again, but adds an incredible flourish wit a handspring and a cartwheel.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBERLY
dialogues.text: They react. No way can they do what Marcia did. One of them raises her hand. at WENDY . Miss Standfast, do we have to do that stuff at the end?

dialogues.speaker: MISS STANDFAST
dialogues.text: No, Wendy. Nobody can do that, except for Marcia... and, of course, me in my day.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: She smiles and combs her long blonde hair.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBERLY
dialogues.text: Come. on. Let’s go check out Greg Brady. The girls move over to watch football practice. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: THE FIELD
dialogues.text: THE WESTDALE FOOTBALL TEAM is exercising on the field. Greg is the halfback and listening to the COACH who is outlining the play to the OFFENSE. The DEFENSE waits for the offense to come to the line of scrimmage.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Okay, men, this is Red B eleven. We’re going to need this in the opener against the Razorbacks. Taylor, you fake the . handoff to Brady. Roll to your right. Brady blocks the defensive end and you complete to Petrie cutting across. Okay, men. Hit it. The offense claps and moves to the line of scrimmage.

dialogues.speaker: THE PLAY
dialogues.text: Taylor, the quarterback, executes the play perfectly. It picks up twelve against the defense. The backfield regroups around the coach.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Once we run this, they’1ll be looking for it. From the same.'formation, Taylor will fake the ball to Brady again, Petrie you do your thing across the middle, but Brady will drift into the flat and get a quick pass from Taylor. Brady should have a clear path up the sideline. It’s Blue B eleven. Hit it.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: They clap again and hit the line of scrimmage. The play works. Greg blocks, then drifts, takes the pass and does a nifty run for a touchdown against the defensive tean.. After Greg spirals the ball back to the quarterback, he is surrounded by the three pretty cheerleaders.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well, Greg, all ready for the Razorbacks next weekend?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Sure am.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So are we. (then, whispering) Can we still count on your help?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (also whispering) Nobody knows about it?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BETSY f Nobody. Not even Marcia. She’d never approve. She’s a Brady.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: So am I.

dialogues.speaker: KIMBERLY
dialogues.text: But you’re not a Brady like she’s a Brady.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: You’re right about that. I/11 pick you up tomorrow. Greg leaves the mysterious conversation, and trots back to the huddle. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Carol drives in in her station.wagon. She carries groceries. She walks to the screen door at the family roo and enters. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks through on her way to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Alice?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol enters and puts down the packages. Still no sign of Alice. .

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (continuing) Alice?! She starts shelving the groceries. One of the groceries is a bottle of Wesson Oil. CAROL . I can’t believe we were running out of this.  we 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Mike’s belts, Alice is tied’'to one of the dining ro chairs which has been moved to the center of the room. She is gagged.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Alice?! Alice tries a muffled response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is puzzled that Alice hasn’t answered. She decides to see what the matter is and crosses to the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol enters and sees Alice on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Alice, what in the world? What happened? Was Sam here? What’s going Still gagged, Alice attempts to answer. Only mumbling sounds emerge no matter how hard Alice tries. Carol start to untie Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Maybe we can answer that. ANGLE - ROCKY, JUNIOR AND CLARENCE - CAROL’S POV They are at the top of the landing. Rocky is now wearing Mike’s clothes. Junior is wearing Greg’s clothes -- which he is a little too big for. Clarence is practically busting out of one of Mike’s suits.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) It appears there was a break in, and the robbers are still in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crooks descend the staircase and approach Alice and Carol. Alice gets out of the rest of the belts.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Alice? Alice rubs her wrists and ankles.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: The worst part was not being able to talk. So I could tell ‘em what I think of them.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I want you all out of my house this minute. : Rocky holds up his gun. Clarence has the other gun, and holds it up as well.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: That’s not what we want. THE PHONE RINGS. Carol looks at Alice who looks at the men.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Who answers the phone in this house?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: If I’m home, I do. ROCKY a You’re home, aren't you? Carol goes to the phone and looks back at Rocky for instructions.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Act cool.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MIKE’S ARCHITECTURE OFFICE Mike is at his desk. He is surrounded by all kinds of renderings, models. Most are marked "Riverside Project."

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hi, honey. Listen, I’ve just got a minute. There’s.a folder marked “Riverside File" on my desk. When Greg gets home, have him bicycle the file to my office. I need it this afternoon. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Okay. (then) Mike...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah? Rocky edges closer. What is Carol going to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (cutely) I loves you, too. Bye, Sweetheart. They both hang up.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY -
dialogues.text: Nice performance, mon.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just take the phone off the hook?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: People report phones that are out of order. Carol suddenly realizes Rocky and Clarence are wearing Mike’s clothes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hey, you’re wearing my husband’s clothes.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (to Junior) And you’re wearing Greg’s.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: (tough) So?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Nothing. We just noticed. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: And you look real good in them.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What say you two sit down while we wait for the rest of the family? Troubled, Carol and Alice sit. cUuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a poorly constructed volcano model, Peter sits next to EUGENE a nerdish student who has fashioned a perfect model of a volcano. Peter has a small battery attached to his. Eugene and Peter wait for the instructor, MR. PERKINS, to check out their projects. Mr. Perkins inspect Eugene’s first. .

dialogues.speaker: MR. PERKINS
dialogues.text: Very nice, Eugene.

dialogues.speaker: EUGENE
dialogues.text: It’s modeled after Mt. Vesuvius. I even put little warning signs in Latin.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PERKINS
dialogues.text: Let’s see it in action. Eugene puts two wires from a nine volt battery together and the volcano makes a sizeable eruption. Mr. Perkins marks a grade.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PERKINS
dialogues.text: Very good, Eugene. He crosses to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PERKINS
dialogues.text: Now let’s see yours, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Mine is Mt. Vesuvius, too.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PERKINS
dialogues.text: - Good. Let’s see the eruption. Peter connects wires from a little battery. “The volcano gives one small pitiful bloop, and one little dribble.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (lamely) I used a smail battery. As Mr. Perkins looks at Peter’s weak attempt, he picks up Peter’s battery...

dialogues.speaker: MR. PERKINS
dialogues.text: Remember this, Peter. The dynamics of an explosion is directly proportional to the influx of the voltage.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What does that mean, Mr. Perkins?

dialogues.speaker: MR. PERKINS
dialogues.text: The bigger the battery, the bigger the boom. cuT TO AND CAROL’S BEDROOM Carol, Alice, Rocky, Junior and Clarence are all at the safe. Carol is trying to open it. Rocky has a gun on her.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Lady, I’m telling you for the last time. Open it! CAROL o And I’m telling you: I don’t know the combination.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Then we’ll just have to wait for Mr. Brady to get home. (hefts the gun)

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Look, if you two will just leave now, we promise we won’t say anything. Here, take my credit cards.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY . /
dialogues.text: Thanks, but Clarence here don’t look much like "Mrs. Carol Brady". Besides, we need cash.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Take my car. I promise I won’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Sure. As soon as we drive away, you’d call the cops with the license number.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, I won’t. I don’t even know my license number. I’m not even sure of the color, or the model, or the make or anything.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR .
dialogues.text: Dad, maybe we should try another house. These Bradys seem like nice people.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: We are. We’re very nice people. of all the people we know, we’re the nicest.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I don’t trust nice people.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Alice, we’re not that nice. cuUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg is walking with his school books toward the house. The unsuspecting Greg opens the front door and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg enters, throws his books onto the couch.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Hi, Mom, I’m ho -- Before he can complete the word, he is grabbed by Junior and wrestled into the living room where he is thrown onto the couch next to Carol and Alice.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Sorry if I hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: You didn’t hurt me, but when I get through with you, you’1l wish... Carol stops Greg by pointing to Rocky and Clarence, who hold guns on then.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: You’11 wish what, cowboy?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Be cool, Greg. They’re just waiting for your father to get home.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: What’d Dad do?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Your father is going to give us everything in the safe. Rocky strolls over to the window and looks out. ANGLE - DARRYL’S CAR - ROCKY’S POV Darryl pulls up and parks in front of the Brady house.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Anybody you know have a red Transam?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: That’s Darryl’s car. JUNIOR . Darryl’s your brother?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No. He’s Marcia’s new boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: Marcia and Darryl are parked in front of the house. It’s gooey pre-kissyface.

dialogues.speaker: DARRYL
dialogues.text: Marcia, I dig you the most.

dialogues.speaker: . MARCIA
dialogues.text: I like you, too, Darryl.

dialogues.speaker: DARRYL
dialogues.text: I’ve got something I want to show you.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: (misinterpreting) I won’t look, Darryl. We already talked about that. I’m a Brady.

dialogues.speaker: DARRYL
dialogues.text: I’m talking about this.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He reaches into the glove compartment and takes out a picture.

dialogues.speaker: DARRYL
dialogues.text: (continuing) Your copy of the senior prom picture. I was so happy you were my date.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: I was happy for you, too.

dialogues.speaker: DARRYL
dialogues.text: You sure look good. Although no picture can do you justice.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: Yes. That is a problen.

dialogues.speaker: . DARRYL
dialogues.text: And I/11 see you Saturday night after the amateur show?

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: Well, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg appears at the car window. He taps on it. Annoyed, Marcia rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: (continuing) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: (urgently) Mom wants you to come inside right now.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: What’s so important? They look toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Junior steps out. He waves.

dialogues.speaker: DARRYL
dialogues.text: Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Marcia, you told Darryl about your new boyfriend, Junior, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: . DARRYL
dialogues.text: Junior?

dialogues.speaker: . MARCIA
dialogues.text: Honestly, Darryl, I don’t know what Greg's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: _ GREG
dialogues.text: Come on in, Marcia. You know how jealous Junior gets. Marcia allows herself to be ushered toward the house as the perplexed Darryl drives away.

dialogues.speaker: GREG AND MARCIA
dialogues.text: As Marcia house.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA 2
dialogues.text: Greg Brady, I’1l never talk to you again as long as I live.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: That might be sooner than you think. is puzzled and she and Greg disappear into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a quiet moment :as Rocky holds his gun on Carol, Ali Greg, and Marcia.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Peter and Jan enter. They stop in their tracks in the entry area as they see what’s happening.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (waving the gun) Come on in. Join the party. Peter notices the hand holding the gun.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, I saw you on TV. The 1-2-3 tattoo on your hand. You’re Rocky Portugal.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: That’s right, kid.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And you broke out of prison. That’s really cool. Then Peter sees Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And you’/re Clarence Dawkins? Clarence just nods.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ' (continuing) Wow!

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Glad you’re impressed,.kid. Now why don’t you sit down before I kill you? Peter immediately sits on the couch with the others. Jan passes by Junior. —

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (to Junior) Did you break out of prison, too?

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he’s my son, and he’s the guy who sprung me. And he’s as tough as we are.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: He’s kind of cute, too. Jan sits on the couch, very deliberately close to Junior.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Bobby and Cindy return home. Both carry lunch boxes. They don’t see what’s happening immediately and Cindy yells as she enters. CINDY . Mom! Bobby arrested me in school again.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I had to, Mom! She was running in the halls! Now they see Rocky and Clarence holding guns on their family. Cindy responds with a loud scream! She keeps screaming.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (to Carol) ~ Mom,.tell her to shut up. Carol goes to Cindy.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Things are okay, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (looking at the gun) No, they‘re not. She screams again. t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiger enters barking. He has heard the scream. He starts for Rocky.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Junior, take care of the dog. BOBBY . Please! Please don’t hurt Tiger.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (lisping away) We'll report you to the A.S.P.C.A. Junior exits into the kitchen for a moment as Rocky guard the Bradys.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He reaches into his lunch box and pulls out his water pistol. He aims it at Rocky.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Might as well put down your weapon, Mister. I’ve got a gun, too. Rocky looks at Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but mine isn’t leaking. Bobby looks at his squirt gun. Indeed, water is running out of it. Rocky takes the gun from Bobby’s hand and squirts water in the little boy’s face.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Folks, this ain’t no game. We don’t care if we have to shoot all of you. Cindy screams again. Everyone looks at her. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: I can‘t help it. Getting shot scares me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Tiger at his heels, Junior returns with a beer can and a bowl. Junior pops it open and pours it for Tiger who laps up the beer happily, belches and staggers off.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You can’t keep us here like this.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Yes we can. You kids go to your rooms. If you try anything funny, your mommy is a memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike Brady drives his convertible into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters angrily.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hi, Honey, I’m home.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 4s

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Carol enters from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Mike, I have something to tell you...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) First, I have something to tell you. I made a simple request: Have Greg bring the Riverside drawings to my office. How tough is that? They didn’t arrive, and I’m meeting with those people tomorrow. The most important meeting in my life! (calling off) Greg, I want to see you in my den! Mike starts to his den.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: But, Mike...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It’1ll have to wait. Carol shrugs as Mike disappears into the den.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAIRWAY
dialogues.text: Greg appears. He passes Carol as he descends.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Does Dad know?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Not yet. INT. MIKE’S DEN Mike is fuming. Greg enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: When you lost my blueprints on your bike that time, I thought you’d learned some responsibility. But apparently, I was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: But Dad...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Greg, but I’m going to have to ground you for two weeks. Booker T. Washington once said, "Few things help an individual more than to place - responsibility upon him, and to let him know you trust him." Well, you have failed that trust.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: But, .Dad, there’s a reason.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: There is absolutely no excuse. Absolutely none.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Brady... Mike turns and sees Rocky at the entrance to the den. Rocky has his gun pointed at then.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (weakly) Q Well, maybe not "absolutely". Rocky waves his gun at Mike.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Pops.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What about the other kids? Is everybody okay?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Everybody’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: They’11 stay fine if you do what you’re told. Mike follows Rocky out of the den. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence is holding a gan on Alice, Marcia, Peter, Jan, Bobby, and Cindy. Junior is in charge of this group.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How long do you crooks expect to hold us here?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JUNIOR ur I’m not a crook. My father is.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Actually, breaking him out of prison and holding us like this makes you a crook, too.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: But he’s my father.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Tell that to the judge.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: You know how it is. Your parents tell you to do something, you do it, and don’t think about it because they’re your parents. Right, Clarence?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE -
dialogues.text: Don’t know. I never had any parents.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MIKE AND CAROL’‘S BEDROOM Mike is at the safe, but he stops before opening it. Rocky, Carol and Greg look on.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’/m telling you: There’s nothing in here.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I find that tough to believe.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: There are things in here, but nothing that you’d be interested in.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Open it up. Mike opens it. Rocky pushes him out of the way. Rocky pulls out items -- unusual items for a safe. The first is a large mayonnaise jar which he shakes.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: The kids’ baby teeth. Now he pulls out papers and a photo album.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: And these things?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Birth certificates, report cards, letters the kids sent us from camp. Pictures of our trips to Hawaii, the Grand Canyon and Cincinnati.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Come.on! Where are the valuables?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Those things are valuable to us. Rocky is getting angry. He grabs Mike by the collar. Greg tries to pull Rocky away. Rocky shoves Greg roughly and Greg falls back on the bed. Rocky now holds a menacing gun on them both.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Are you okay, Greg?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m okay. .

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (to Mike) Listen, clown, I’m getting sick of you and your goody-goody family. And your shining little faces, and your report cards and your jars of baby teeth and pictures of Cincinnati. I want your money, and I want it now.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I don’t have any money. ROCKY . No money? I don’t get it, Brady. You’re a fancy architect, and you design a house with one bathroom for six kids, and force them to live three to a room.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (helpfully) Once he installed a pay phone to cut down on our phone bill. We even do our own wallpapering.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: That just proves he’s saving all his dough. Where is it, Brady?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED, (2)
dialogues.text: Rocky digs back into the safe, and pulls out a bankbook, and holds it up triumphantly.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Never mind. Rocky sees the balance and whistles.

dialogues.speaker: . ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) So that’s where all your dough is. In First Federal. Carol looks over Rocky’s shoulder, and is equally surpris by the large amount. Mike gives her an embarrassed "I’1l explain later" shrug. °

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (to Rocky) This is the weekend. The bank is closed.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Come on. Rocky waves them toward the door. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is seated on the couches and chairs and Rocky -- like General Patton addressing the troops -- spells ou what the plan is. Jan has positioned herself next to Junior again. Cindy holds Kitty-Carry-All. ROCKY . *, Because the bank won’t open till Monday, Me and Junior and Clarence have decided to spend a fun-filled weekend with your family. . The others react to this news.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: +..Then on Monday, I’m going to the bank with your dad, and he’s going to pay us handsomely for entertaining you people in your own house. Rocky laughs at his own remark.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Adlibs of 50

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: What about our act at the Bowl Saturday night?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: And my Little League Game?

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: And my cheerleader practice?

dialogues.speaker: . CINDY
dialogues.text: And my Sunflower Girl meeting?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What? What are you people talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We have a very active family. If we don’t show up for all our activities, people will be suspicious. If I were you, I’d leave right now.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Well, you ain’t us. (reconsiders) But we don’t want anybody nosin’ around here. (then) Okay, you can do all the things you’re talking about. excited victory until...

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (indicates his gun) But nobody try anything funny. Like callin’ the cops, for instance. (grabs Carol)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Get your hands off her!

dialogues.speaker: . ROCKY
dialogues.text: Well! Here come the Marines!... Calm down. Nothing’s gonna happen to her as long as you all behave. CAROL — Kids, get washed up for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Clarence, go along with then.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’ll just stay here with Mrs. Brady.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. Cindy leaves her doll on the couch, and joins her family, they go off to wash up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brady family members are all in their traditional Places in their seats. Two chairs are pulled up on either side of Carol for Rocky and Junior. Rocky has his gun on the table next to him. Junior sits next to Marcia. Jan is none-too-pleased. Clarence sits in another chair next to Cindy, who is close to screaming at all times. He is an eating machine, and pays no attention to anything goin on at the dinner table. Alice brings out a _Platter of fo and puts it down. Rocky immediately digs in, and has awfu eating habits. Everyone looks at hin.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? Haven’t you ever seen a man eat before?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE S
dialogues.text: We'd like to say grace.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Say what you want. I’m eating. As Rocky stuffs his face...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lord, for the bounties you have given us and please continue to look out for us at all times -- especially this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: ALL BRADYS
dialogues.text: (except for Rocky) Amen. Rocky punctuates the blessing with a loud belch. Cindy screams. Peter stands up, and as he heads for the kitchen Rocky grabs his gun.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I’m just getting some ketchup. ROCKY . Okay, kid. But remember, I don’t like surprises.  52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice is cooking dinner. Peter comes up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Alice, do we still have those big cell batteries that. we took on the camping trip?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: They’re on the service porch. Why? Peter doesn’t answer. He disappears to the service porch. cuT To

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: (to Junior) Would you care for some gravy?

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: I‘d. love some. Marcia ladles some gravy on his food. As she does, she brushes against him. He enjoys the contact.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Jan sees Marcia scoring.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Give him some more gravy, Marcia. Be sure to lay it on real thick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is at the refrigerator, then ducks down. Three very large cell batteries are hooked together and a wire runs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: THE WIRE
dialogues.text: We follow the wire. Peter has rigged an electric charge to run under Rocky’s chair. He starts connecting the terminals. Unbeknownst to him... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Bradys continue to pass food from one to the other Mike tries to put his family at ease.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: This is a difficult time for all of us, but as L.P. Jacks once said, "Man is ill adapted for living an easy life, but he is well adapted for living a difficult one."

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I don’t like where I’m sitting.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I should be at the head of the table.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (indignantly) This is where I always sit.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Right. When you used to run the family. Get up, bub. As Mike and Rocky rise to change places...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter doesn’t realize that Rocky and Mike have changed seats as he kneels by his batteries.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (to Alice) Well, here goes nothing. He places the two wires together, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Mike leaps into the air and dashes around the room yelping in pain. Peter comes running in.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did I get him? Did I get him? Peter stops as he witnesses the plan gone astray. Clarenc grabs Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Whoops. Rocky stands and assumes control as Carol comforts Mike.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I said, "No games." From now on, nobody gets out of our sight.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What happens when we go to bed? Rocky thinks about it, then...

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: You all sleep together. In the living room -- where we can keep an eye on you. And if there’s the slightest bit of trouble... Rocky picks up his gun and shoots... ANGLE - THE COUCH ae Kitty Karry-All is blasted apart by Rocky’s shot.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: She starts screaming. The SCREAMING CONTINUES AND BRIDGES THE... cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are on, and all the furniture has been pushed to the sides. Nine sleeping bags are laid out on the floor. Each Brady is in pajamas, and standing next to his/her sleeping bag. Alice, in her classic sleepwear and pin curlers is next to her sleeping bag. Rocky, Junior and Clarence are on the first landing of the stairs, guns still in evidence.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Okay. When I need some shut-eye, Junior or Clarence will take over.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 55 LD CONTINUED. GREG Do Wait a minute. We were going to rehearse tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: That’s right. Tomorrow’s the big amateur contest at The Hollywood Bowl.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: (impressed) You’re performing at the Bowl?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes. We have to win that contest tomorrow night. It’s real important.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Too bad. No rehearsal. No Bowl.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: If the kids don’t show up there, someone’s going to show up here.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: What do we care, Dad?) Let them rehearse. .

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Maybe you’re right.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Great. Let’s rehearse. The kids get up, start out.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Where you goin’?

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: To the platform in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh uh. You rehearse right here, or you don’t rehearse at all.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: I guess we rehearse right here. The kids start up the stairs. Clarence moves to block their path.

dialogues.speaker: . MARCIA
dialogues.text: : ) We need our costumes. We can’t rehearse AL in our pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (waving the gun) Rehearse. Mike, Carol, Alice and the kids all push the sleeping bag out of the way. Peter crosses to the tape machine which is on a table in the living room, and turns it on. It’s a different song than the one we heard earlier. It’s "Goo Time Music". Mike, Carol, Alice, Rocky, Junior and Clarence observe as the Brady kids sing and dance.

dialogues.speaker: GOOD TIME MUSIC
dialogues.text: ALL: Let me hear some of that good time music, That I love to hear. GREG: I’ve got plenty of blues, And sort of bad news,

dialogues.speaker: GREG/MARCIA
dialogues.text: And I need to find me some cheer. MARCIA: Well, there’ve been some times, When I’ve been down, , More so recently. GREG: I've got a piece of bad ride, Make a new flight.

dialogues.speaker: GREG/MARCIA
dialogues.text: React positively. ALL: There’s no sense in walking around, With your feet stuck in the ground. MARCIA: It’s much better, To put yourself together, GREG: Create a lot of love and good vibes, For humanity. ALL: That’s fine with me. The Brady kids do as well as they can, considering the circumstances, in their night clothes, on the living room -floor, and with Rocky, Junior and Clarence observing. As they sing and dance:  57

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad, they’re not bad.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Are you nuts? I ought to plug three or four of them right now, and save the world some ear aches. The kids are about halfway through the number when:

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Okay, kids. You’re finished.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We‘re not through yet.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (threatening with his gun) Yes, you are.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE -
dialogues.text: You heard him, kids. .

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Talk about a tough audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Brady Family starts pulling the sleeping bags into position again:

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: The house is dimly lit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the Bradys are in their sleeping bags. Rocky, Junior and Clarence are on the landing, keeping guard.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: Jan, I’m really scared.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Come on. This is the first neat thing to happen to this family since you broke your nose.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (whispers) Hey, guys, I have to go to the bathroon.

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: What do you want us to do? Pee for you.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: But Rocky says we can’t be out of his sight.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Just hold it, Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Till Monday? \_ Greg moves over to Rocky.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY AND GREG
dialogues.text: Greg goes

dialogues.speaker: GREG
dialogues.text: Bobby has to go to the bathroon.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Thanks for the bulletin. back to Peter and Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing, to Junior) Watch everybody. I’m going to take Bobby to the bathroom. .

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: You never took me to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Okay, from now on, I’1l take you to the bathroon.

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: I‘1l take the kid.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. Clarence and Bobby go upstairs toward the kids’ bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: As he crosses to Marcia’s sleeping bag.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Marcia, I’m sorry about all this.

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: It’s not your fault, Junior. I know that. :

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: If things were different, I’d...I mean if I weren’t who I am, and you weren’t who you are, do you think there might be a chance... you know?

dialogues.speaker: MARCIA
dialogues.text: That’s hard to say.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Then it’s not a no?

dialogues.speaker: JAN AND CINDY
dialogues.text: They are witness to this whole thing, and Jan is jealous once more.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What does she have that I don’t have?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Junior, INT. BOYS’ AND GIRLS’ BATHROOM Bobby is peeing. Clarence is nearby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Clarence, do they have bathrooms in prison?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That’s terrible. You guys got to hold it while you’re in there?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: They got toilets in the cells.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: But cells don’t have doors. Just bars. Right?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: The whole front is just bars.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: And everyone can look in and see what you’re doing?

dialogues.speaker: CLARENCE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I sure don’t want to go to prison. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: As CAMERA PANS the sleeping Bradys, and arrives at Mike who is half-dressed in clothes he had prepared. A shirt, pants. He picks up his shoes and construction hard hat, and starts to exit quietly. The others are asleep.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Going out a little early, aren’t you, dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocky has intercepted Mike. Rocky makes no attempt to whisper and the others wake up during...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I wasn’t going to turn you in or anything. I was just going to my meeting.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: It’s the big Riverside project. I’ve been working on it for two years. I’ve gotta make a living.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: So do I. So sit down and shut up. Rocky takes the hardhat from Mike’s hand and throws it down.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t say anything. You’ve got my whole family here.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: Maybe yes. Maybe no. I don’t like maybes. He pushes Mike down on his sleeping bag. Rocky turns to Alice. i

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) And you get in the kitchen and fix some breakfast. Alice goes immediately.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing to the others) Gee, it’s fun having a housekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocky leaves Junior and Clarence in charge of the others, and enters the kitchen as Alice starts to prepare breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? Afraid I’m going to slip something into your food? ROCKY ; No. I just like a good meal. At prison we were lucky if they slipped food into our food. THE FRONT DOOR BELL RINGS. Rocky immediately tenses up.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (continuing, to Alice) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: T don’t know. Rocky goes through the archway into the sleeping bag lade living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocky crosses to Mike and Carol, Junior and Clarence.

dialogues.speaker: ROCKY
dialogues.text: (to Carol) Whoever it is get rid of them. (then to Junior) You two, hide. But keep ‘em covered. Carol looks to Mike who shrugs an okay. Carol puts on her robe, which is next to her sleeping bag, and crosses to the front door. Junior ducks into the doorway to Mike’s den. Rocky retreats toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Carol opens it for Sam, who carries a package.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hiya, Mrs. Brady.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hello, Sam. Did we order something?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No ma’am. This is a present for Alice. CAROL . I’m afraid she can’t see you right now.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: She’s still mad. Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (seizing on it) Right. That’s it. You know how women are, Give her some time to cool down and come back a little later. Like Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: “Tuesday?" What I have to say can’t wait till Tuesday, Mrs. Brady. He barges in and.starts across the living room. He stops for a moment as he sees all the Brady kids in sleeping ags.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (continuing) Campin’ out, campin’ in, square dances, slumber parties. You guys always got something going. He passes through the archway into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam enters and finds Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
